newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Security summit overshadowed by Russian fears.
newsitem.headline: Security summit overshadowed by Russian fears.

text.p: A European summit sets out on Monday to lay the foundations of peace for the 21st century but with divisions and animosities of the past casting long shadows.

The 54-nation Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) aims to agree at a meeting in Lisbon on a blueprint -- a security model -- for closer cooperation between countries that were on different sides of the Cold War.

Encouraged by the OSCE's recent success in organising elections in Bosnia, government leaders from North America and all of Europe will look at ways of strengthening the organisation and boosting its effectiveness.

Since its birth in 1975 in Helsinki as an East-West forum for discussing issues from democracy to economics, the security body has played a key role in bringing about arms reductions, organising ballots and giving early warning of looming ethnic conflicts in the former Soviet empire.
But the challenge facing the 54 member states -- there were 55 but Yugoslavia was suspended in 1992 -- is to decide where the organisation should go from here.
Russia, deeply suspicious of NATO plans to expand up to its borders, wants an ever greater role for OSCE as a counterbalance to the U.S.-led military alliance.
President Boris Yeltsin, who is recovering from heart surgery and will not be in Lisbon, called for the summit to aim for a "new architecture of European security."
Aides quoted him as saying at a meeting on Friday with Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, who heads the delegation to Lisbon, that Russia remained firmly opposed to NATO expansion.
"Russia's stance on NATO expansion remains unchanged, that is, negative," spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky quoted him as saying.
Washington rejects any link between the expansion of NATO, with Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic expected to join before the end of the century, and the development of OSCE.

Others are also reluctant to agree to Russia's proposals for strengthening the European security forum -- even though diplomats say a failure to address Russian concerns could mean more opposition from Moscow as NATO takes in new members.
As closed-door sessions continued on a draft document, there were signs of disagreement between the U.S. and some of its European allies over how to handle Moscow.
"Some feel that we should move towards Russia, extend it a hand, while the Americans see no need," said one OSCE official.
But on one issue -- that of arms reductions -- diplomats were confident that progress could be made that would go some way towards reassuring the Russians.

They said that they expected the summit to agree that fresh negotiations on cutting military hardware should start in Vienna next year. The Russians have long argued that current accords are out of date because they were drawn up when Europe was divided into two armed camps.
The last OSCE summit in Budapest in 1994 was wrecked by a row over the Bosnian war and warnings from Yeltsin that NATO risked plunging Europe into a "Cold Peace".
Like Yeltsin, President Bill Clinton will also not be in Lisbon. The U.S. delegation is headed by Vice President Al Gore.
Russian concerns over NATO remain, but the overall European mood has improved since Budapest when the bloody fighting in Bosnia was deepening a sense of international impotence.
"We are not in the same situation at all. The atmosphere is a lot calmer," said one European diplomat.

But the expected presence of President Alexander Lukashenko of Belarus, who recently won a highly controversial referendum extending his powers, will be a reminder of the multiple problems still to be resolved.
Lithuania has suggested to fellow neighbours Poland and Ukraine that they hold a regional presidents' meeting in Lisbon to discuss Belarus's constitutional turmoil.
